cause.description:
My friend, Sameer Bhatia (www.helpsameer.org), has been diagnosed with Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML). He is in urgent need of a bone marrow transplant. Sameer, a Silicon Valley 31 year old just got married last year. His diagnosis was confirmed just weeks ago.
Sameer, a Stanford alum, is known to many for his efforts in launching the American India Foundation, Project DOSTI, TiE (Chicago), and other causes focused on helping others. Now he needs our help in giving him a new lease on life. He is undergoing chemotherapy but needs a bone marrow transplant to sustain beyond the next few months.
Fortunately, you can help.
Things You Can Do 1. Get registered. Getting registered is quick and requires a simple cheek swab (2 minutes) and filling out some forms. Registering and even donating if you’re ever selected is VERY simple.
Another friend of ours, Vinay, was also diagnosed with AML and requires a transplant. We have joined forces with Team Vinay (www.helpvinay.org) in order to get South Asians registered in the bone marrow registry. Both Sameer and Vinay need a match from another South Asian, however, very few South Asians are actually in the registry. This is why we need your help.
We are supporting Team Vinay in organizing drives nationwide, and I need you to get registered by visiting a local drive. Drives are currently taking place all over the country. Please see the full list of locations here: http://www.helpvinay.org/
2. Spread the word. Please share this message with at least 10 people (particularly South Asians), and ask them to do the same. Please point your friends to the local drives and ask them to get registered. If you can, sponsor a drive at your company or in your community. Drives need to take place in the next 2-3 weeks to be of help to Sameer and Vinay.
Thank you for getting registered to help Sameer and Vinay win their fight against leukemia – and for helping others who may face blood cancers in the future.
1. Help Find Bone Marrow Matches For Leukemia Patients
2. Increase The Number of Minorities In The National Marrow Donor Program
3. Increase Awareness About Being A Bone Marrow Donor
